docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration today ordered the infant-formula industry to run frequent tests on the nutritional quality of its products. It said the tests must be made during the manufacturing process and during shelf life to ensure that adequate nutrients are provided. An F.D.A. spokesman, Wayne Pines, said that the new regulations, which will take effect 90 days after they are published in the Federal Register, would cost the industry $2 million initially and $1.3 million a year thereafter.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the parent of a hydrocephalic, severely retarded 2-year-old, I want to address the ''in-between'' zone that Dr. Golbus cites as his biggest worry - those cases in which the baby is neither cured nor dies, but sustains a severe handicap. Though the article did mention that a possible side effect of technology is saving a fetus but leaving him brain damaged for life, more attention needs to be given to this subject.
